node.accessibility_caption: Photo by KC • Pediatric PT on July 29, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, child and text that says 'AILESTONES MOTHERHOOO & STUCK IN STANDING?! Environment set up & tips to help if your little one go from stand to sit'.

node.text:
STAND >> SIT. Your baby is getting into standing & then getting stuck or has become a master of the trust fall... what the heck do you do!? ⠀
⠀
Here is a few ideas with videos to help! ⠀
⠀
Picture 1: suction cup toys are GREAT- using them on a window or even the fridge at varying heights will encourage partial squatting, which you can then gently guide into squatting all the way to the floor. ⠀
⠀
Picture 2: cruising is a big compliment want to this, because it really works bending the knees and starting to explore more independently! If your little one isn’t cruising yet, try taking the cushions off or getting something right around belly height for them to cruise along with enticing items on top!
⠀
Picture 3: THIS ONE IS HUGE! cruising along descending height furniture. Set up the environment for success (have I said that too much lately 🤣). Couch cushion to cushion removed, to diaper box, to amazon box is a good progression. And again, once they’re in that partial squat, help them gently down! ⠀watch this little ones BEAUTIFUL motor planning as she moves downward!
⠀
Picture 4 & 5: assisted stand < > squat from your legs. Your legs are usually the perfect height to start from (a short stool works too). The key is to gently tip their trunk forward to move their weight towards their toes & encourage that stand. ⠀
-To get back down from there, you’ll do the same thing, but in reverse. Gentle pressure to help them bend at the waist and then guide them down. ⠀
⠀
Let me know if this helps, and if you have any other questions about squat to stand! And don’t forget the walking masterclass has TONS more tips, link in bio! 

Tag me in your practicing videos & tag a friend that may find this helpful!

node.text:
Hands up if you love bubbles! 👋

They are one of my favorite therapy tools to encourage a whole bunch of really awesome things- so here’s my to 4! 

1) work those abdominal muscles! We use our core muscles for everything.... literally everything! Getting them engaged and active in a variety of ways is huge for function, and this one is so fun! Start with them seated upright, and play with how reclined they are. Flatter = harder and more isolation to abdominals, rather than the muscles that bend your hip. You can move it to the right or left, higher or lower, and even have them point or flex their toe to bring in other muscles. 

2) tip toes gets a bad rep, but it’s actually a really important skill! Think of reaching something on a counter, pushing off on your toe during walking or running, stair climbing, pointing your toes to kick a ball- those calf muscles have to be strong- and this is a great way to do it! 

3 & 4- work that hand eye coordination! Start by catching it and allowing them to motor plan how to pop it. Then, advance to letting them follow & pop it as it falls! You can also work on kicking with the same two methods; just encouraging their feet instead. 

So tell me below, what’s your favorite bubble activity?!

node.text:
Jumping ministones! 

Generally speaking, jumping with clearance of both feet is expected around 24 months of age. Some littles will be earlier, some will be slightly later- and as with anything, development is a range and that is usually totally okay! 

Here’s what to watch for to know that jumping may be on the horizon…. 

+bouncing in standing (on a soft or hard surface) when jumping is modeled (knees bending only) 
+bouncing in standing and rising onto toes- which preps the calf muscles for the big contractions needed to jump successfully 
+bouncing in standing and lifting one foot while rising on toes 
+leaping forward when jumping is modeled 
+leaping OFF something like a step when modeled 

And then - full blown jumping! It will start as jumping straight up, clearing both feet, and then progress to things like jumping forward, jumping to the sides/backward, jumping over an obstacle, and jumping off of something (like a step). 

Let the fun begin! Is your little currently doing any of these things?!

node.text:
Let’s talk rolling ministones! How do you know rolling might on the horizon?! 

Rolling belly to back often occurs around 3-5 months, and begins as an accidental roll because the weight of their head causes them to topple over. Between 4-6 months, back to belly rolling often emerges as the front muscles engage more, but 6 months is more of the average ((Don’t panic if your baby does the opposite order- it can be common & is usually totally ok!)) 

So- some signs that rolling may be coming soon (these don’t all HAVE to happen either!) 

BELLY TO BACK: 
+pressing up on hands when on belly 
+lifting head high and looking around 
+attempting to free one hand and play with a toy on belly 

BACK TO BELLY: 
+grabbing feet
+rolling to side & back 
+playing in sidelying
+hands to midline for toys (the middle of their body)

If you’re not seeing any of these signs that rolling is coming by 8 months, I’d mention it to your ped and see about a PT eval- but remember that development is truly a range!

Tell me- have you seen any of these?! Don’t forget to cherish those ministones when you can- without them, there’d be no big milestones to celebrate! 

And don’t forget, all this and more covered in depth in my ROLL/SIT masterclass (link in bio).

Let the good times roll! 😏

node.text:
Walking ministones- here we go!

remember- ministones are those really special things we sometimes lose sight of that our little ones do on the way to the big anticipated milestone! 

In the case of walking- check out these ministones: 

+pull to stand with hand support usually begins soon after crawling (often 9-10 months)
+cruising along furniture with hand support 
+letting go with one hand while standing 
+letting go with both hands while standing 
+transitioning in/out of standing 
+transitioning between two close by objects (brief periods of letting go) 
+taking steps while holding an object 

Some others you might see: 
+steps with a push walker (I would rather see this than steps while holding their hands)

Independent walking is expected between 12-18 months from a textbook standpoint. BUT as a peds PT, I’m much more comfortable with 16 months. If you’re not seeing some of these strong ministones that indicate walking is coming by 16 months, OR your little seems to be “stuck” for more than a month or two on one of these ministones- don’t be afraid to push for a PT Eval! 

So... which of these is your little one currently doing, or which ones did you notice on their way to full blown walking!? 

And remember- link in bio for my walking class, which has this and so, so much more laid out to set the environment up and play purposefully to support your little one through these stages! ✨

node.text:
Y’all know by now I love mini “inch”stones- the little things that add up to equal the big milestones we typically anticipate. I might even love ministones more than I love full blown milestones, because they are things we often take for granted or don’t realize are SO special, and so exciting on the road to the milestone. 

So - let’s talk about crawling ministones! 

+Pivoting on their belly (often begins around 4-5 months)

The rest often come after pivoting on the belly & can vary on when they present… 

+Pushing backwards on their belly 
+Planking 
+Inching forward on the belly 
+army crawling *may or may not happen*
+rocking on hands and knees 
+bear position (on hands and feet with booty in the air) 
+a few creeps on hands & knees before dropping to the floor again 

Typically, crawling on hands and knees is expected between 8-10 months. Some are earlier and some may be a touch later, but if you’re not seeing these strong signs that crawling is coming soon around 10 months, I would just mention it to your ped. 

So,tell me - did you notice your little doing any of these, or are they currently?! I can’t wait to hear!

And don’t forget, crawling masterclass (link in bio) has lots of tips to encourage these ministones and work towards the big crawling milestone!

node.text:
Looking for some easy activities to help bring your elevated little one to a calmer state? If you’re seeing lots of running, crashing or bumping into people/things, tripping/falls, poor body awareness in their environment, hitting/kicking associated with excitement....give these a try! 

Heavy work & proprioceptive input are some of the best ways to calm the body & help allow your little one to regulate themselves.  What works best for one child will be different from another, so theee may take some trial and error, but these simple activities can have a huge impact and are some of my go to’s during therapy AND with my own kids! 

+pushing a weighted down laundry basket (towel under if you’re worried about scratches)
+pulling a weighted laundry basket 
+inclined rolling
+squishes with cushions/pillows 
+bear hugs 
+crab crawling, wheel barrel, bear crawling 
+*safe* tug of war- let them do the pulling and you stay solid- don’t pull back!
+push/pull squigz or other suction toys to fridge 
+feet push offs- make sure their feet stay in contact with you the whole time, and give some resistance to their push! If you have a child that tends to kick, skip this one 💛

So, have you tried any of these?! Let me know how they work for your little one if you do!

node.text:
Little ones arm holding them up in rolling? 

Make sure their arm position is like this! We want thumbs up, which creates space in the shoulder joint from an anatomical standpoint. If their arm is down by their side like first shown here- that creates a thumbs down position, which is pretty difficult (if not impossible) to roll over efficiently. 

Making sure they’re thumbs up, and then encouraging arm to be AT or ABOVE shoulder height will make the roll functional & allow them to get their weight shifted enough to roll. 

When you’re helping- think: 
THUMBS UP 
ARM UP
ROLL! 

If they’re still struggling right at the end to get that arm out and finish the roll, try gentle pressure down on their bottom towards their toes- like shown at the end. 

Remember- this and a ton more is covered in depth in my ROLL/SIT masterclass! Link in bio 🌻

Hope this helps- Drop your questions below and tag a parent that could use this tip!

node.text:
My top 2 easy to implement core strengthening activities! ⠀
⠀
Here’s the thing, core strengthening can benefit anyone! Often times, when there is underlying weakness, the core and proximal muscle groups (shoulders and hips) are most involved. These 2 activities hit those groups, encourage strengthening, and are fun & easy to modify depending on where your little on currently is in terms of ability level.⠀
⠀
1)Elevated sit ups (Video 1& 3)- as much as we think we all want a 6 pack, believe it or not, the trunk rotation muscles (primarily the obliques) are the powerhouse core muscles that we use for just about every functional movement pattern. It’s how we get off the floor, rotate our trunks when walking, and generally are active just about every moment of the day! The key with this isn’t for them to sit straight up, it’s for them to tip to the side and come up through a push on their hands. MOST people have a side that is easier - if you try it on yourself you’ll likely notice that too, so make sure to do both sides! Start on your legs or elevated on a pillow, wedge, whatever you have! As you try this and your little one gets strong, work towards being closer and closer to flat on the floor. ⠀
⠀
2)Wheelbarrel walking (video 2)- this one is so fun and is so easy to modify, and it’s huge for shoulder and core strengthening! You can start by just having them stay in one place while you hold them in the wheelbarrow. Progress to lifting one hand and reaching for something that’s a touch higher up (think - a toy on top of a small box that they can reach for). As this gets easier, work on wheel barrel walking, and have fun with it! ⠀
The biggest key with this one is to make sure their stomach isn’t sagging. If it is, your hands are too low on their body and they need more help. Back should be straight at all times - like the proper plank position! ⠀
⠀
Those are my top two, so give them a shot and let me know how it goes! Drop your questions below & tag a parent that could use this info!⠀

node.text:
Is your little one so close to independent steps, but lacking confidence or needing you to hold their hands? 

Try this hack! 

Place two chairs or pieces of furniture close together, with motivating items on top. Encourage them to start by turning their body while holding on with both hands still. As they become more stable, move the chairs further apart to encourage a few steps, and voila! 

Have you tried this?! Did it help? Drop your questions below and tag a parent that could use this info- AND for lots more tips on how to get your little one walking, check out my walking masterclass that covers everything from pulling to stand to independent walking & balance (link in bio) 🙌

node.text:
Struggling with your little one not putting weight through their arms? Here’s a trick- it’s all about toy placement! Why? Vision & reflexes!

See in that first video how when she’s looking up at her mom she’s up on hands, and as soon as her vision drops to the toy that’s below her visual field, she drops right down? That’s because vision & reflexes drive extension or flexion of the arms. Meaning, when the gaze is up (above eye level), the arms extend. When the gaze is down (below eye level), the arms tend to flex. 

So, use that to your advantage! For younger babes, put toys or a book like in the second video, just above eye level. 

When babes are a bit older, like the little one in the third video, try assisted hands and knees. See how with the toy below eye level, there’s a ton of Superman going (not a bad thing at all & a totally necessary reflex, but can be frustrating for them and us, check out Superman highlight for more!), but when she’s in assisted hands and knees with toys above eye level, she’s way up on hands and even reaching with one side? *chefs kiss!*

So, is this news to you!? Try it out and let me know how it goes, drop any questions below, and tag a parent that could use this info!

*if your child is visually impaired or Blind, try using auditory toys and the supports as shown in my tummy time highlight to encourage more extension of the head and arms!*

node.text:
I know stairs & furniture safety can be intimidating. We often avoid it because the worry of an accident can be so overwhelming. But what if, instead, we started teaching our babies the safe way as soon as they’re mobile? I promise, they will get it, & it’ll be one less thing for us to worry about as parents! Because don’t we have enough as it is 🥴

As soon as your little one is on the move, teach them to flip to their bellies and slide down off furniture. You can apply this to the stairs too, if it works for you! 

Repeat repeat repeat, you’ll be doing the majority of the work at first, but I promise, before you know it- they’ll have that safety skill nailed down! 

Give it a try & let me know how it goes, & tag a parent that could use this info!
